climbs.name: Bushido
climbs.fa: Luka Bogdanovic and Blake Burbank, January 8th, 2022

content.description: Bushido is a worthwhile and fun addition to Wingman that can also been seen from the road if it's in. Wingman in green, Busido in red. Photo courtesy of Drew Brayshaw. After topping out Wingman, wallow your way up about 70 meters of snow gully above with a couple of rock/ice steps to surmount before getting to a large boulder and the 50 meters of ice.  We climbed the flow next to the boulder, fought through a couple frozen bushes (hence the name), and connected with the steeper upper section. A more adventurous line could go via chimneying and stemming off the boulder and into the ice on the corner. Three 60 meter rappels gets you to the base of Wingman.  See approach details for Wingman. Standard ice rack.

climbs.name: Wingman
climbs.fa: Shaun Neufeld, Maxim de Jong, January 2017

content.description:
Formerly known by a different name (W.G.), this route climbs a the left side of the major gully directly above the start of the FSR. 

 There are two independent lines, both on the left side of the canyon. Wingman climbs the lower angle pillar on the left to where the ice narrows next to a small roof, past this is a lower angle ramble and then thin ice up the left wall to one final step and a sheltered belay in a bit of a cave.

Rappel 60 meters on a v thread or continue up the thin ice/rock step at the top onto Bushido WI3+ above. 



Wingman is found directly above the start of the Hunter Creek FSR, you should be able to easily see if it's in from the road and parking area. Scramble directly up the gully from the road, depending on conditions the approach can take from 15 minutes to an hour of post holing.

Standard ice rack.
A number of quality ice lines can be very easily accessed from the Hunter Creek FSR just off of Highway 1. The FSR is actively used so watch out for heavy machinery and be smart about where you park.
